properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Visibility in blowing snow is expected to deteriorate tonight as southerly winds increase. There may be intermittent improvement but generally wind gusts near 80 km/h will cause poor visibility in blowing snow until Friday morning. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T13:33:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T21:34:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3683302975.2020
Area: Paulatuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected to develop early this evening. Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow will persist until early Thursday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T13:41:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T21:42:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1128356468.2020
Area: Sachs Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds expected beginning Friday. Total snowfall: 15 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 100 km/h or higher along the Mid Labrador Coast. Locations: Labrador. Time span: Friday through Saturday night. Remarks: Snow is expected to spread across Labrador on Friday. The snow may change to rain or freezing rain over southeastern parts of Labrador Friday night before changing back to snow on Saturday. On Saturday, strong northwesterly winds are expected to combine with snow along the Labrador Coast to bring poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions will improve by Sunday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-20T00:06:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T08:07:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3720453854.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chill values near minus 45 are expected to develop tonight then moderate on Thursday as temperatures rise. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T13:33:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T21:34:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3929657145.2020
Area: Fond-du-Lac, Stony Rapids and Black Lake, Cree Lake - Key Lake, Wollaston Lake - Collins Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Reduced visibilities in snow and blowing snow continue for Clyde River. As the wind speeds increase this morning, near-zero visibilities in blizzard conditions are expected to return and continue until this evening, when winds will slightly ease and visibilities will improve. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-20T00:19:49-00:00

Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential winter storm for the end of the week with snow and blowing snow. A low will track into Western Quebec Thursday night and move quickly eastward. Total snowfall amounts could vary between 15 and 25 centimetres. In addition, visibilities will deteriorate rapidly in heavy snow and blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T18:42:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T02:43:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3016677187.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and blowing snow expected Thursday evening into Friday morning. An approaching low pressure system will track over Lake Huron late Thursday bringing snow to Northern Ontario. Snow will begin over the area Thursday afternoon and become heavier through the evening. Snow will gradually weaken Friday afternoon. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected. There remains some uncertainty in the exact track of this low and the northern extent of the highest snowfall amounts. Snowfall warnings may be required as the situation becomes clearer. Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions Thursday evening into Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T17:40:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T01:41:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1601399069.2020
Area: Moosonee
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Spring storm Friday with snow, rain, awinds and risk of freezing rain. A low will track into Western Quebec Thursday night and move quickly eastward. Precipitation will begin as snow on Friday morning before changing over to rain during the day. A short period of freezing rain is also possible during the transition. Significant amounts of snow and rain are likely. Strong winds will also accompany this storm. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T18:45:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T02:46:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2430423158.2020
Area: Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area, Minganie, Natashquan, Chevery, Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Thursday evening into Friday. An approaching low pressure system will track over Lake Huron late Thursday bringing snow to Northern Ontario. Snow will begin over the area Thursday afternoon and become heavier through the evening. Snow may mix with rain Thursday evening. Snow will continue into Friday before gradually tapering off Friday evening. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected. There remains some uncertainty in the exact track of this low pressure system and the precipitation associated with it. Should the low take a slightly more northerly track than anticipated, more of the precipitation will fall as rain and lower snowfall amounts will result. Snowfall warnings may be required as the situation becomes more clear. Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions Thursday evening into Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T17:55:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T01:56:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2645257637.2020
Area: Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind expected to end the week. Total rainfall: generally 30 to 50 mm with locally higher amounts possible along the south coast. Maximum wind gusts: generally 80 km/h except locally 120 km/h or higher in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: southern and western Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning through Saturday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Friday morning, and then quickly transition through freezing precipitation before changing to rain at times heavy late Friday. Snowfall amounts are not expected to be significant at this time. Strong winds will also develop Friday morning, with the highest gusts occurring over areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Conditions will improve Saturday morning. Milder temperatures will accompany the rainfall and will cause significant snowmelt and runoff leading to potential flooding. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-19T23:48:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T07:49:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0863093898.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Thursday into Thursday night. An approaching low pressure system will track over Lake Huron late Thursday bringing heavy snow to Northern Ontario. Light snow will begin over the north shore of Lake Superior tonight, becoming heavy during the day Thursday. Snow, at times heavy, will continue into Thursday evening before gradually weakening Thursday night or early Friday morning. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected by the time the snow comes to an end. Motorists are advised to prepare for difficult travel conditions Thursday and Thursday night. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T17:54:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T01:55:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0485497627.2020

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum Les Suetes gusts: 120 km/h. Time span: Friday morning until Friday evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR BURNS LAKE AND SMITHERS The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory for Burns Lake and Smithers because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-19T17:12:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-19T01:13:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1339917566.2020
Area: Bulkley Valley, Lakes District
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and blowing snow expected Thursday evening into Friday. Light snow will begin over the area late tonight or Thursday morning. The snow will slowly increase in intensity through the day and will become heavy by Thursday evening. Heavy snow will continue Thursday night before slowly tapering off Friday morning. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are expected by the time the snow comes to an end. In addition, northerly winds gusting up to 50 or 60 km/h are expected Thursday night into Friday morning resulting in blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Additionally, strong northerly winds gusting up 60 km/h will begin this morning bringing reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain Thursday night followed by snow Friday. Rain is forecast to begin near Manitoulin Island Thursday evening and will spread northeastward to reach areas near the Quebec border Thursday night. The rain will be heavy at times, with amounts in the 15 to 25 mm range possible by the time the rain tapers to showers early Friday morning. The showers are then expected to transition over to snow with the passage of a strong cold front during the day Friday. At this point in time, snowfall amounts are not expected to be heavy, but a few centimetres of accumulation are possible. Rainfall warnings with the criteria of 25 mm within 24 hours may be required at a later time should heavier rainfall amounts become more likely. There remains some uncertainty as to the exact track of the low pressure system responsible for the rain and snow. As such, some changes to the forecast are possible. Environment Canada will continue to monitor the situation closely and update the forecast accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T17:59:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T02:00:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3667053042.2020
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Greater Sudbury and vicinity, West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa, Blind River - Thessalon, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain and freezing rain Friday. A low will move over Western Quebec on Thursday night. Northern Abitibi could see between 10 and 15 centimetres of snow while the south gets rain. These areas could receive up to 30 millimetres of rain by Friday afternoon. Freezing rain may occur near snow-rain boundary. Be prepared for variable winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Temperatures dropping to mid minus 30s and moderate winds will lead to wind chills near minus 45 Thursday morning. Wind chills will moderate by Thursday afternoon. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T18:16:53-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain Thursday night changing to heavy snow Friday. Rain is forecast to begin near Lake Superior Thursday evening and will reach areas near the Quebec border Thursday night. The rain will be heavy at times, with amounts in the 15 to 25 mm range possible. By late Thursday night into Friday morning, the passage of a strong cold front will cause temperatures to rapidly fall and any rain will change over to snow. A brief period of freezing rain is possible during this transition. The snow, heavy at times, will then continue through the day Friday before tapering off Friday evening. 10 to 20 cm of snowfall can be expected by the time the snow comes to an end. There remains some uncertainty as to the exact track of the low pressure system responsible for the rain and snow. As such, some changes to the forecast are possible. Environment Canada will continue to monitor the situation closely. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T17:11:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-19T01:12:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2258528740.2020
